courses.description: This course aims at helping new students to develop an understanding and appreciation of university education and to adapt to campus life. Origins, traditions and objectives of universities, and their relationships with individual and society will be introduced. Distinctions between adult learning and juvenile learning, high-school and university studies will be elaborated. Advice and effective social and study skills will be provided to facilitate smooth transition. The Founder’s Ideas and the WS (Woo Sing) Spirit will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College Year 1 students only
2. Not for students who have taken GEWS1012
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:
·
Learn the Founder’s ideas and the WS (Woo Sing) spirit;
·
Understand the University’s origins, traditions and objectives;
·
Learn specific study and social skills; and
·
Raise their community awareness
courses.course_syllabus:
1. University Education
· The meaning of university education
· The role of university student
2. Personal and social skills
· Personality and potential
· Dining etiquette
· Social etiquette and grooming
· Mental wellness
3. Relationship between individual and the community
· Social equity
· Meaning of social service
· Biodiversity Conservation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
·
Term-end course evaluation questionnaires for collecting qualitative feedback from students;
·
Feedback from students in class, through WebCT and email; and
·
Face-to-face consultation
courses.required_readings:
A. Expectation on university study
• Brinkworth, R., McCann, B. Matthews, C., Nordstrom, K. (2009). First year expectations and experiences: Student and teacher perspectives. Higher Education, 58(2), 157-173.
• Crisp, G., Palmer, E., Turnbull, D., Nettelbeck, T., Ward, L., LeCouteur, A. Sarris, A., Strelan, P. & Schneider, L. (2009). First year student expectations: Results from a university-wide student survey. Journal of Univesity Teaching & Learning Practice, 6(1), 11-26.
• Leung, S. A., Hou, Z. J., Gati, I. & Li, X. (2011). Effects of parental expectations and cultural-values orientation decision-making difficulties of Chinese University students. Journal of Vocational Behavior, 78, 11-20.
B. Adjustment and orientation
• Kantanis, T. (2000). The role of social transition in students’ adjustment to the first-year of university. The Journal of Institutional Research, 9(1).
• Pancer, S. M., Hunsberger, B., Pratt, M. W. & Alisat, S. (2000). Cognitive complexity of expectations and adjustment to university in the first year. Journal of Adolescent Research, 15(1), 38-57.
• Sevinc, S. & Gizir, C. A. (2014). Factors Negatively Affecting University Adjustment from the Views of First-Year University Students: The Case of Mersin University. Educational Sciences: Theory & Practice, 14(4), 1301-1308.
C. Group Work and Communication
• Chen, Y. F., & Peng, S. S (2008). University students’ Internet use and its relationships with academic performance, interpersonal relationships, psychosocial adjustment, and self-evaluation. Cyber Psychology & Behavior, 11, 467-469.
• Colbeck, C. L., Campbell, S. E. & Bjorklund, S. A. (2000). Grouping in the dark. The Journal of Higher Education, 71(1), 60-83.
• Tsay, M. & Brady, M. (2010). A case study of cooperative learning and communication pedagogy: Does working in teams make a difference? Journal of the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning, 10(2), 78-89.
• Troth, A. C., Jordan, P. & Lawrence, S. A. (2012). Emotional intelligence, communication competence, and student perceptions of team social cohesion. Journal of Psychoeducational Assessment, 30(4), 414-424.
D. Cultural Diversity
• Hu, S. & Kuh, G. D. (2003). Diversity experiences and college student learning and personal development. Journal of College Student Development, 44(3), 320-334.
• Hung, R., McClendon, J., Henderson, A., Evans, Y., Colquitt, R. & Saha, S. (2007). Student perspectives on diversity and the cultural climate at a U.S. medical school. Academic Medicine, 82(2), 184-192.
• Lawrence, J. (2005). Addressing diversity in higher education: Two models for facilitating student engagement and mastery, in Higher education in a changing world, Proceedings of the 28th HERDSA Annual Conference, Sydney, 3-6 July 2005: pp 243.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: The Art of Leadership
courses.description: A team is a group of two or more people who have a common objective or purpose with a commitment to collective and incremental improvement. Great teams, like great leaders, are made, not born. Two concepts, trust and commitment, are the glue that holds teams together. The objective of this course is to train the students to be a leader who can foster these two aspects of the team.In this course, the students will learn the attributes of trust-building and commitment-building through lectures, workshops, and outdoor activities. The students will also participate in team projects designed by the College. By this chance, they will practise their knowledge and skills through thorough guidance by College supervisors.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Wo Sing College students only.
courses.component:
Debate
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
Workshop
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Explain the nature, purpose and structure of a team
• Equip with the individual attributes that contribute to success of teamwork
• Differentiate the roles and responsibilities within teams
• Communicate effectively in a team
• Strengthen their understanding and awareness of problem solving within a team

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: General History of China
courses.description: This course aims at introducing the main course of changes in Chinese history and the value of Chinese cultural heritage. Through lectures and discussions, it covers major issues in development of Chinese history. Examples of the topics include the origin of Chinese culture, milestones in dynastic history, intellectual thoughts and social structures. Field trip and tutorial help students to understand the relationship between Chinese history and Hong Kong development. After taking this course, students are expected to develop critical thinking and analysis skills in a historical context, and further interests in the learning of Chinese culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for History Majors.
3. Not for students who have taken UGEA2230.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
• acquire a general knowledge and understanding in Chinese history.
• appreciate how the humanistic values and societal structures evolve and develop from traditional to modern China.
• criticize and evaluate issues in contemporary Chinese communities in a historic context.
• identify the relationship between Chinese history and Hong Kong development.
• develop further interests in the study of Chinese culture.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: China and The World
courses.description: Napoleon Bonaparte once said of China: “China is a sleeping lion. Let her sleep, for when she wakes she will move the world.” Today, China has risen to become the second largest global economic power; and some experts even predicted that her economy is poised to overtake the US economy by year-2035. Is Napoleon’s prophecy going to come true? China has remained an enigma to the rest of the world. Traditional China’s accomplishments towards medicine, painting, architecture, martial art music and dance had impressed the world and her inventions such as paper, gunpowder, compass, and printing had helped move Europe to the modern age. This course aims to examine the evolvement of the Chinese civilization and factors affecting how China interacts with the rest of the world. It will also explore the extent and impacts of intercultural exchanges between China and the world. The course will also look at the role Hong Kong played in China’s interaction with foreign powers in the past and assess opportunities afforded Hong Kong in the implementation of the Chinese “One Belt, one Road” initiative.In conclusion, the course will assess the swift rise of contemporary China, and the aftermaths brought by her rapid industrialization. The course will try to answer if China will fulfil Napoleon’s prophecy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be be able to:
- Explain the artistic, philosophical and scientific inventions and discoveries made by the Chinese in historical as well as contemporary China and understand their impacts in history as well as in today’s world
- Identify the routes in which Chinese discoveries and ideas travel to other parts of the world and the consequences of such cultural interchanges.
- Compare and contrast the roles played how Hong Kong and Guangzhou in the exchange process.
- Appraise and evaluate issues faced by the today’s world when China flexes its cultural and economic muscles in international circles.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part A. China and its culture
- Background information about China: its location, geography, languages spoken and factors leading to the rise of imperial China.
- A survey of Chinese cultural attributes: its artistic, philosophical, religious and scientific and technical constituents
Part B. History of Cultural Exchanges between China and the world
- Land Silk Road and Maritime Porcelain Route
- Cultural exchanges with Japan and Korea
- Contact with the Roman empire- Silk Trade
- Contact with India- Buddhism
- Mongols and the West- Marco Polo
- Contact with Europe-Jesuits
- Contact with America
Part C. Modern and Contemporary China
- Republic of China- World War II
- People’s Republic of China - Cultural Revolution and the Four Modernisations
Part D.
- The Role of Hong Kong in Chinese history and in the future.
- Discussion: Peaceful rise of a new World Power or threat to World Peace
Student presentations

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Future of Food: Plant-based Living

meetings.location: Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R
Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R
Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R
Lee W.S, Anthony T.Y.Wu Sem Rm
Lee W.S, Anthony T.Y.Wu Sem Rm
Lee W.S, Anthony T.Y.Wu Sem Rm

courses.description: This course helps students to understand the major concepts, theories, debates and reflections related to plant-based lifestyle. Particular thematic issues such as global warming and pollution, food crisis, diet and health, animal rights, social justice as well as green economy related to livestock industry and food system will be examined. The course encourages students to observe and evaluate the impacts of omnivore diet and lifestyle to their personal life, the animals and the planet as a whole.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
• Examine the main concepts related to plant-based lifestyle, such as types of plant-based diet, development and consciousness in Hong Kong, modern livestock industry and global warming, correlation between diet and health in terms of nutrition, Chinese and Western medical science, animal rights of food animals and non-food animals and marketing direction of this movement
• Differentiate the vegetarian food culture among countries and identify the variety of vegetarian.
• Be exposed to the main controversies resulted from livestock industry, e.g. health, global warming and pollution, food crisis, animal rights, social justice, etc.
• Have the ability to form independent idea and justification about the causes, norms, impact and controversies of the animal-consuming culture and lifestyle by applying the concepts covered in the course
• Have the ability to explore and apply plant-based alternatives towards current animal-consuming culture and lifestyle
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Why we eat pigs but love cats?
2. Does taking public transport help us to reduce carbon footprint?
3. How many chickens do our planet carries?
4. How about the protein?
5. Cigarettes Vs Sausage – Which does more harm to our body?
6. Doesn’t eating vegetables makes our body too “Han”?
7. Outing: Plant-based grocery shopping and restaurants
8. Omnivore or plant-based – Is this a personal choice?
9. Keeping pets means loving animals?
10. Why vegetarians and vegans are still minorities?
11. Where do we go from plant-based diet?

2. Does taking public transport help us to reduce carbon footprint?
Gerber, P.J., Steinfeld, H., Henderson, B., Mottet, A., Opio, C., Dijkman, J., Falcucci, A. & Tempio, G., Tackling climate change through livestock – A global assessment of emissions and mitigation opportunities, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), Rome, 2013, Chapter 3, “The aggregate picture”, pp. 15-21 < http://www.fao.org/docrep/018/i3437e/i3437e.pdf>

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Evolution of Universal Communication: Debate and Application
courses.description: This course examines the nature of manner and etiquette systems in the context of interpersonal as well as intercultural communications through exploring its history and development. As part of the social norms, manner and etiquette systems seem to be more universal with increasing socializations in a more globalized world, especially in the business sector. There are still ongoing debates that some countries still preserve their own manner and etiquette systems in some splendid ceremonies and events. This course further studies the factors and socialization processes that shape manner and etiquette system, while specific application will refer to the culture of business in term of practices and behaviours.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will cover the following topics:
1. History and development of manner and etiquette system
2. Comparison of manner and etiquette system among countries and cultures
3. Theoretical discussions on interpersonal and intercultural communications as well as socialization
4. Business etiquette and Protocol

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Nature's Classroom: Field Studies of Nature's Genius in Biodiversity
courses.description: This course aims to introduce nature’s genius in the diversity of flora and fauna of Hong Kong and other places. It is specially designed for students in their second year of study or above. The goal is to raise students' awareness of nature’s hidden beauty and genius, including biodiversity and biomimicry. Coursework includes lectures and outings led by experts in their fields, field trip reports, analysis and interpretation of wildlife films in class, feedback on video-clips, a multimedia art exercise, and a biodiversity quiz. Students will learn to appreciate and treasure biodiversity through guided tree walks, bird watching, butterfly photography, and powerful ideas of Nature as our mentor, measure and model in solving human problems. No prior knowledge of biodiversity, or training in multimedia or photography is required, but a sense of wonder, a spirit of inquiry, and passionate curiosity in Nature’s genius.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.component:
Classwork
Discussion
Field Studies/Field-trip
Independent Study
Lecture
Web-enhanced Teaching
Workshop
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. appreciate the importance of learning from nature as their mentor, measure, and model and to apply what they learn to solve real-life problems
2. tell others some of the biodiversity hotspots in Hong Kong and suggest ways to protect them
3. develop a spirit of inquiry, and draw on Nature’s genius in the idea of biomimicry
4. tell the human impact on climate change and its disastrous consequences on biodiversity
5. find and show compassion for all living creatures and Nature as whole and take actions to save endangered species and ecosystems
courses.course_syllabus:
Major concepts and topics to be covered include:
1. The concept of biodiversity and topics related to Hong Kong as examined by practical field studies
a. Hong Kong Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (HKBSAP)
b. Trees of Hong Kong
c. Birds of Hong Kong
d. Butterflies of Hong Kong
2. The concept of biomimicry in relation to biodiversity and evaluation of its applications
a. Learning from Nature
b. Biomimicry in action
3. Biodiversity and Sustainable Development
a. Design for sustainability (e.g. visiting an experimental farm with aquaponics)
b. Ecological solutions
4. Biodiversity Conservation and Climate Change
a. Global warming since the Industrial Revolution
b. Biodiversity decline factors: H.I.P.P.O.
i. Habitat loss (including climate change and extreme weather)
ii. Invasive Species
iii. Pollution
iv. Population explosion
v. Over-harvesting
Fieldwork: There will be two field trips to Hong Kong’s rural areas including country parks.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Innovation in Service Industry
courses.description: This course provides an understanding of the nature of innovation related to the growth, success and future development of the service industry on the local and global scales. This course aims to provide students with an understanding of how both anticipated and unanticipated changes may influence tourism, hospitality and MICE (i.e. Meeting, Incentive, Convention and Exhibition). The roles of innovation and creativity in responding to change are also emphasized. Consequently, the course addresses aspects of key management problems, needs, developments and approaches that effectively utilize technology and innovation in the service industry. It also encompasses an understanding of various information and other technological methods utilized in the functional areas of development, operations, management, marketing and financial management.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for Hotel and Tourism Management majors or Hospitality and Real Estate majors or students who have taken HTMG1010.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
• Discuss and analyze the key factors responsible for the growth and development of service industry (i.e. in particular, hospitality and tourism industry).
• Describe the current trends and challenges faced by the service industry (i.e. in particular, hospitality and tourism industry), in the context of global economic, environmental, health and other social concerns.
• Identify types of firm innovations and discuss how they can be applied to improving elements of a firm’s operation.
• Participate and communicate effectively in problem-based learning teams and with industry.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course covers three major sections including hospitality industry, and tourism industry
Section 1: Sprit of Service
Increasingly strong competition within the service industry and the continued clamor of guests for new and exciting experiences, has raised the importance service excellence plays in the success of any hospitality operation. This module will help students develop the kind of positive and caring guest service attitude that will enable students to outdo themselves each time.
Section 2: Innovation in Hospitality Industry
The hospitality industry—comprising of businesses that serve guests away from home- can be defined by its scope, mission and providers. This module will help students understand the nature of the hospitality industry, its overall service mission, and the many career paths you can opt to pursue, within this very dynamic and exciting industry.
Subsections – Innovation performance in Chain and Independent Hotels, Innovative Project Development in Hotel/Restaurant Operations, etc.
Section 3: Innovation in Tourism Industry
Tourism is a 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 52 weeks a year economic driver. This module will help students understand the economic impact of tourism and how it benefits you as it offers the greatest global employment prospects.
Subsections – Analyzing the Innovation Potential throughout the Tourism Value Chain, Challenges in Mobile Business Solutions, etc.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Experiencing the Kunqu and Peking Opera
courses.description: Kunqu and Peking Opera are Chinese classical traditions and cultures. The aim of this course is to nurture students' appreciation ability and to deepen their understanding on Kunqu and Peking Opera.This course serves as a foundation to further study at an advanced level and encourages future participation in Kunqu and Peking Opera performance.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Understanding Globalization
courses.description: This course helps students to understand the major concepts, theories, debates and reflections related to globalization. Particular thematic issues such as economy, environment and sport as well as non-traditional security issues in the fields of humanitarian intervention, terrorism, nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking and global health will be examined. The course encourages students to observe and evaluate the impacts of globalization to their personal life as well as the role of Hong Kong between the East and the West in the era of globalization.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for students who have taken UGEC2514 or UGEC2990/ANTH2520
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
• explain the main concepts such as regionalism, global governance and interdependence which are related to the processes of global economic, social, political integration.
• examine and analyze the main controversies resulted from globalization processes, e.g., trade liberalization and the “race to the bottom”, human rights and sovereignty, global market forces and the goal of nature conservation, and the challenges of non-traditional security issues.
• appraise and evaluate the causes, impacts and controversies of globalization by applying the concepts covered in the course.
• associate the macro-level factors of globalization to current affairs in Hong Kong society.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course covers 4 major sections: Introduction, theoretical frameworks and empirical cases as well as a flipped classroom in the last 2 lectures.
The introductory section mainly discusses the concept and background of globalization and how it is relevant not only to international organizations, states, sub-national actors, but also ordinary people.
Section 2 introduces different theories and analytical frameworks which help students to understand and explain globalization.
Section 3 focuses on various thematic issues of globalization such as economy, environment, sports, human rights, terrorism, and other non-traditional security challenges.
The last section works like a flipped classroom that each student has a chance to present his or her understanding on globalization according to the assigned role.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Food Psychology and Healthy Eating
courses.description: You are what you eat. In modern society, food consumption not only fulfils basic human physiological needs but also greatly impacts people’s fitness and wellbeing. This course helps students to understand the psychological processes and factors underlying their food choice and eating behaviour and acquire knowledge and skills in developing healthy eating habits in college and beyond. Main topics covered in this course include the development of eating behavior, social influences on eating, food choice and consumption behavior, eating disorders and treatments as well as developing healthy eating habits.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for Hotel and Tourism Management majors or Hospitality and Real Estate majors.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
• Understand the main psychological concepts, theories and processes relating to food choice and eating behavior such as classical conditioning, associative learning, mere exposure and priming, social influence and self-regulation
• Develop and reinforce heathy eating habits by applying the knowledge and skills acquired in the course
• Be able to critically evaluate marketing and sales messages and make informed food consumption decisions
• Improve group communication and teamwork skills and strengthen students’ bond with each other and with the college
courses.course_syllabus:
The course covers the following main topics:
1. The development of eating behavior: Chapter 5 (Rowland and Splane)
2. Social influences on eating: Chapter 5 (Rowland and Splane) & Chapter 4 (Conner & Armitage)
3. Mood, affect and food: Chapter 6 (Rowland and Splane)
4. Dining out behavior: Chapter 7 (Germov and Williams)
5. Food choice and food marketing: Wansink (skim the whole book)
6. Eating disorders and treatments: Chapter 9 (Rowland and Splane)
7. Developing healthy eating habits: Albers (skim the whole book)

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: History from Words: Experience the Beauty of Literature
courses.description: This course will give a survey of the development of modern Chinese literature. By reading selected works of major authors, this course investigates the thoughts, the artistry and the significance of modern Chinese short stories, novellas and poems. Besides, it gives a survey of the development of Hong Kong literature by reading the works of major authors. The relationships between literature and history, as well as between literature and society, will be emphasized. The artistic quality of Hong Kong literature and its place in modern Chinese literature will be evaluated.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for students of Department of Chinese Language and Literature.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
1. describe the general contemporary history of China and Hong Kong through reading modern literature
2. master the concept of post-modern history and understand the mediating role of narrative text in historical narrative
3. recognize the humanism, value of diversity and creativity through literature reading
4. cultivate the habit of reading literatures
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will cover the following topics of modern literature:
1. Chinese Poetry
2. Chinese Fiction
3. HK Literature
4. Modern Literature
5. Autobiography / Biography of Modern Historical Figure in China

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: The Rise of Populism in Europe
courses.description: This course covers a wide variety of material and is highly relevant in understanding rapid changes in Global and Comparative European Politics. Part I of the course provides a brief historical background to European politics and sets the scene for the course, in examining theoretically how contemporary ‘populism’ is defined and conceptualized in the 21st century political landscape. Part II of the course provides the main focus of the course, in focusing on the main causes and drivers that have led to the growth of (a) radical right-wing populism and (b) radical left-wing populism. Three key approaches are drawn on in Part II of the course, with comparative studies, survey research (public opinion) and case studies across Western Europe and Central-Eastern Europe allowing students to understand about the diversity and variations of populism in the contemporary political landscape. Part III of the course introduces students to critical debates and evaluations on the ‘rise’ of populism and just how important understanding this political phenomenon is for (a) the implications for contemporary democracy and governance in EU member states, alongside (b) how populism on the ‘right’ and ‘left’ of the political spectrum is challenging the future EU project. Part III of the course also draws briefly on comparisons between the primary causes of ‘populism’ in the European context, to the causes of ‘localism’ in the Hong Kong context.The final part of the course also revisits the premise and assumption made in Part I of the course, about the historical stability of the European political landscape by outlining how a shift has taken place, with ‘a new form of politics’ now existing in European politics. Stability and patterns of partisan alignment have now been replaced by instability and widespread patterns of electoral volatility.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for students who have taken GPAD3160.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
• Understand what contemporary ‘populism’ is and the different variants of this political ideology (Populist Radical Right-Wing and Populist Radical Left-Wing Parties)
• Understand the primary ‘causes’ that have led to the rise in electoral support for populist parties on both the right and left of the political spectrum
• Understand how the governance of a number of EU countries is currently under threat, with events such as the ‘rise’ of populism, the landmark Brexit vote (‘Euroscepticism’), the Migration/Immigration Crisis, the economic crisis and the decline of social democratic parties in 21st century Europe)
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1- Introduction to the History of European Politics
Week 2- The Formation of the European Union, the ‘Traditional’ Political Landscape in Europe and ‘A New Form of Politics?’
Week 3- ‘A Political Earthquake?’ Defining ‘Populism’ as a Political Ideology
Week 4- Causes of Radical Right-Wing Populism in Western Europe: The Cases of France, the Netherlands and Germany
Week 5- Causes of Radical Right-Wing Populism in Central-Eastern Europe: The Cases of Hungary and Poland
Week 6- Causes of Radical Left-Wing Populism: The Cases of Greece, Spain and Britain
Week 7- The 2016 Brexit Vote I: A Special Documentary
Week 8- The 2016 Brexit Vote II: The Future of British Politics
Week 9- Special Lab Session: Understanding Public Opinion in 21st Century Europe
Week 10- The Decline of Social Democratic Parties in Europe: Key Explanations
Week 11- The Future of European Politics and the EU (SPECIAL GUEST LECTURE/SPEAKER FROM THE EUROPE ASIA POLICY CENTRE FOR COMPARATIVE RESEARCH)
Week 12- ‘A New Form of Politics?’ ‘Populism’ in Europe v. ‘Localism’ in Hong Kong: Comparisons
Week 13- Conclusion Lecture: Is Populism a threat to liberal democracy in Europe? (Roundtable and Interactive Discussion in the Lecture)

courses.recommended_readings:
Due to the rapid ‘rise’ of populism across Europe, there is no current textbook that can account for such systematic changes in European Politics. As a result, this course will utilize a number of interactive online readings/resources alongside latest cutting-edge peer-reviewed journal articles. These online resources are outlined below in more comprehensive detail and supplementary op-ed articles will also be posted to the Course Blackboard page weekly.
ONLINE RESOURCES:
The European Union
The official website of the European Union. Offered in 20 different languages, this website is useful for students.
http://europa.eu
Eurobarometer
Public opinion surveys conducted by the European Commission since 1974.
http://ec.europa.eu/commfrontoffice/publicopinion/index.cfm
European Social Survey
The European Social Survey (ESS) is an academically driven cross-national survey that has been conducted across Europe since its establishment in 2001. Every two years, face-to-face interviews are conducted with newly selected, cross-sectional samples.
The survey measures the attitudes, beliefs and behaviour patterns of diverse populations in more than thirty nations.
http://www.europeansocialsurvey.org
European Union Academic Programme Hong Kong (EUAP)
The EUAP is designed to strengthen EU-Hong Kong relations through academic activities and network building with local, regional and European partners. Regular public seminars are held alongside policy briefings and exchange trips across the EU.
http://euap.hkbu.edu.hk/main/
YouGov
https://yougov.co.uk/news/categories/europe/
British public opinion company that is world leading in the design and implementation of political surveys. The polling company has regular polls that examine attitudes towards Europe of British citizens.
BBC
Latest breaking news and updates on EU politics.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world/europe
Le Monde (English version)
Up to date news on Europe by a leading French newspaper
http://www.lemonde.fr/le-monde-in-english/
Der Spiegel (English version)
Up to date news on Europe by a leading German newspaper
http://www.spiegel.de/international/

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Hong Kong Myths
courses.description: As an international city, Hong Kong has been praised in world class financial services; one of the most efficient governments in the globe; a vibrant and pluralistic globalized city which can serve as the bridge between China and the West even after the handover in 1997. The above Hong Kong myths are valid to some extent, but very often people in Hong Kong have neglected the successful driving forces behind. More importantly, could Hong Kong’s successful development be sustained in a long run? This is an introductory course on contemporary Hong Kong issues. This course applies an interdisciplinary approach and aims at introducing students to basic concepts from Hong Kong’s economics and trade, to administrative and political system of Hong Kong, as well as the role of Hong Kong in international relations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to
• Understand various driving forces behind Hong Kong myths such as world class financial center, a leading efficient government in the globe and an international city that links up China and the West.
• Explain the process and factors that have shaped Hong Kong’s development in the fields of neo-liberalism, small government with executive-led system and Hong Kong as a global gateway.
• Evaluate the trend of Hong Kong’s development and better prepare their career plan and development after graduation.

Class 1 – Introduction
Class 2 – The Colonial Legacy
Class 3 – Economic Myth: The Road to International Financial Centre
Class 4 – Economic Myth: A Small Government
Class 5 – Political Myth: What is Executive-led System?
Class 6 – Political Myth: A Most Efficient Administrative System?
Class 7 – Cultural Myth: Interested Groups and Mass Media
Class 8 – Cultural Myth: A Global Civil Society?
Class 9 – Global Myth: Hong Kong’s External Relations
Class 10 – Model Legislative Council
Class 11 – Model Legislative Council
Class 12 – Model Legislative Council
Class 13 – Roundup: The Future Development of Hong Kong

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: The Beauty of Chinese Painting
courses.description: This course introduces the materials and tools, techniques in brushwork, ink tone variations, and colouring to beginning students of Chinese painting. It also focuses on the techniques of painting in an expressive manner i.e. in the literati tradition of “writing the idea”. In this regard, Chinese calligraphy and painting techniques, as well as the forms of expression are covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for Fine Arts Majors.
courses.learning_outcomes:
通過修讀本科，學生應可：
1. 瞭解與初步掌握中國畫基本的工具，為表達自己的心境與想法打下一定的基礎；
2. 整個科目貫穿書法的學習與練習，能以書入畫，於畫作題字；
3. 瞭解東西方文化不同的繪畫表達，知道各自長處與特點，也可以借鑒西方藝術表達方式；
4. 體會東方美學精神，學會在「虛白處做文章」，如何體察自己的內心，尋找合適的表達語言，做到「無中生有」。
courses.course_syllabus:
內容:
1. 對工具如筆、墨、硯、紙的瞭解與使用方法，線條練習與熟悉水與墨的相斥相融。
2. 從書法入手，從歷代書法源變中感受與欣賞書法之美，體現毛筆的魅力與筆力。
3. 中國畫的符號象徵一一《芥子園畫譜》介紹，為何貢布里希《藝術與視覺》推崇為「中國標準繪畫教程」？學會一些物象的表現方法，學會「看到自己會畫的東西」。
4. 中國山水畫導賞與分析，欣賞中國歷代優秀山水畫，從中找到自己的喜愛與方向。
5. 介紹西方繪畫的特點與流變，從東西方繪畫的特點看東方意韻的表達，也學會吸收西方繪畫的意象表達元素。
6. 欣賞與理解中國與筆墨的趣味，通過撞水、撞色、撞粉……等實踐，初步體味水墨的豐富味道。
7. 通過不斷創新的中國山水畫技法，瞭解如「拓印」等手法，學會逆反思維，增加與豐富中國畫的表現力。
8. 介紹近代中國山水畫創新大家劉國松的畫作，通過他的創作拓寬我們的思路與視野。
9. 介紹與欣賞中國畫家走向世界的成功代表人物趙無極，從他的創作理念與實戰中學會中西交融，洋為中用。
10. 課外寫生，經過一段時間的嘗試與實踐，我們走出室外，到大自然、到山野中尋找符合內心表達的物象加以表達。
11. 寫生創作，把上周外出寫生的素材加以整理，把之理想化，形成新的視覺圖像。
12. 無中生有，從心中尋出聽思所想，畫出心中的那個意象，直抒胸臆……這種抒懷會令人產生淋灕的痛快。
13. 超以象外一一這是中國畫最高的境界，也是東方藝術的精髓，通過十二周的課程學習，最後，有一個階段性的綜合、表現與發揮。

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Promotion of Emotional Wellness: Concepts and Practices
courses.description: This course aims to promote students’ awareness and understanding of various issues related to emotional wellness through an online learning platform. The content of the online platform is developed by CLEAR with the collaboration of various teams in CUHK. It covers some common wellness issues encountered by our students, such as perfectionism, anxiety and academic stress.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for Social Work Majors and students who have taken UGED1553, UGED1554, PSYC1020 or PSYC3760.
courses.component:
Independent Study
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course,
Students are equipped and prepared when encountering with emotional problems and the ways to ask for emotional support.
Students develop a sense of self-discipline on their studies with the hybrid designs of e-learning and face-to-face in-depth discussion.
Students master concepts and skills through service-learning group project on promoting mental wellness at college.
courses.course_syllabus:
Concepts of Emotional Wellness
Study the definition of emotional wellness and the emotional wellness of Hong Kong people.
Emotional Wellness Issue: Perfectionism
Discuss the definition, causes, symptoms and effects of perfectionism. Explore strategies in dealing with perfectionism.
Emotional Wellness Issue: Anxiety
Discuss the definition, causes, symptoms and effects of anxiety. Explore strategies in dealing with anxiety.
Emotional Wellness Issue: Depression
Discuss the definition, causes, symptoms and effects of depresion. Explore strategies in dealing with perfectionism.
Emotional Wellness Issue: Academic Stress
Discuss the definition, causes, symptoms and effects of academic stress. Explore strategies in dealing with academic stress.
Emotional Wellness Issue: Suicide Prevention
Discuss what factors for suicidal behaviour, and how to identify people having suicidal motives. Explore strategies on suicide prevention.
Service-learning project on promoting emotional wellness at College
Based on knowleage and skills acquired, design and conduct a project to enhance students' awareness on emotional wellness.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Compassionate Communication: Theory and Practice
courses.description: Compassionate communication helps people remain empathetic with ourselves and each other, even in situations fraught with anger or frustration. It helps us to speak to others without blaming and to hear personal criticisms without withering. This approach can be used in nearly any situation — from dealing with troublesome peers in schools to ironing out rough patches with parents at home.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students are able to
identify the key concepts of compassionate communication
apply the skills of compassionate communication to their daily life
develop their pattern of compassionate communication
courses.course_syllabus:
How communication affects relationship
Introduce different types of communication and explore the connections between communication, self-awareness and people relationships.
Four types of disconnection language
Discuss four types of ineffective communication patterns and identify the disconnection language used by ourselves in daily life.
Presence, intention and attention
Practise three key elements of compassion and communication, which are a) presence, b) intention & c) attention, through in-class activities.
Needs consciousness, emotions and empathy (empathetic listening)
Discuss how needs have been conceptualized as an account for motivation and as a theory of humanity.
Four steps for honest expression
Practise the skills/ steps of compassionate communication, observation, feelings, needs and request through in-class activities.
Difficult conversations
Explore effective response to disagreements or conflicts with others, such as a) blaming the others, b) blaming ourselves, c) self-empathy and d) empathising with the others.
Conflict resolution
Acquire different skill set to resolve conflicts through demonatration, role-plays and case studies.
Basic facilitation for collaboration
Identify roles and types of facilitation, and some easy-to-use facilitation skills to make our work more collaborative.
Compassionate communication and social change
Discuss the application of compassionate communication in real-life cases.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Behavioral Science in Everyday Life
courses.description: Behavioral science is a cross disciplinary approach to understanding the human mind and its decision process. It is a combination of scientific research in social psychology, cognitive psychology, and economics. Behavioral science theories have been used to better understand how humans perceive, think, and make decisions. The objective of this course is to enhance your understanding of the fundamental factors that drive human behaviors. By understand these factors, you may gain better insights into analyzing your own behaviors and developing strategies for behavioral management. For example, we will teach learning theories (how certain ideas become associated with each other over time; how people learn through conditioning processes) and use these theories to explain behaviors we observe in daily lives [1] [2]. We will also discuss three major theories from the Behavioral Economics literature, including “prospect theory”, “mental accounting”, and “hyperbolic discounting / intertemporal choice”. These theories will help us understand how people value money, why human valuation of money does not simply depend on the nominal value of the money, and how people mentally track expenditures. Students who would like to read about these topics before course registration may consult the following one-page articles: [3], [4], [5] We will also introduce a simple model that guides behavioral change. We will discuss the EAST framework developed by the Behavioral Insight Team. Although the framework was originally developed for policymakers to guide their policy development, everyone can use the framework to guide their own behaviors. For a quick introduction, see [6][1] https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/tech-happy-life/201810/why-do-we-feel-so-compelled-check-our-phones[2] https://sitn.hms.harvard.edu/flash/2018/dopamine-smartphones-battle-time/[3] https://www.behavioraleconomics.com/resources/mini-encyclopedia-of-be/prospect-theory/[4] https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/mentalaccounting.asp[5] https://thedecisionlab.com/biases/hyperbolic-discounting[6] https://www.bi.team/publications/east-four-simple-ways-to-apply-behavioural-insights/
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MKTG3020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students are expected to:
Gain a deeper understanding of the motivations and behaviors of humans
Identify what factors shape one’s beliefs and choices in everyday life
Use theories to diagnose behavioral issues (be able to specify principles and concepts in the diagnosis), and come up with theory-based behavior-change solutions. Apply theories and behavioral insights to promote wellbeing through behavioral changes
courses.course_syllabus:
Prospect theory - Prospect theory is a Nobel-Prize-winning behavioral model that discusses how people decide between alternatives that involve risk and uncertainty (e.g. % likelihood of gains or losses). It demonstrates that people think in terms of expected
utility
relative to a
reference point
(e.g. current wealth) rather than absolute outcomes. (
https://www.behavioraleconomics.com/resources/mini-encyclopedia-of-be/prospect-theory/
)
Mental accounting - A behavioral economics concept introduced by Nobel Prize-winning economist Richard Thaler, refers to the set of cognitive operations used by people to organize and track financial activities. Due to people’s limited mental capacity, these operations are often imperfect. Hence, these mental operations often result in biased judgment and decisions.
https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/mentalaccounting.asp
Hyperbolic discounting and self-control - Hyperbolic discounting is our inclination to choose immediate rewards over rewards that come later, even if the immediate rewards are actually smaller than the later rewards. The model helps us understand self-control issues from a theoretical perspective (rather than thinking of it as a will-power limitation).
Associative learning theories - Associative learning theories strive to capture the processes underlying and driving the change in strength of the associations between representations of stimuli that develop as a result of experience of the predictive relationships between those stimuli.
[WMY1]
Associative learning is one of the ways people learn to mentally connect things (ideas, concepts) together. The associative learning theories have been broadly used in many different domains, but in this course we will focus our discussion on the role of associative learning theories in habit formation (which will hopefully shed light on how to develop strategies for changing bad habits and building good habits). We adopt the perspective that habits strengthen through associative and award-learning mechanisms that characterize a slow, incremental nature of habit formation. We discuss the theories in class, and contextualize the theories using examples drawn from daily lives.
System 1 and System 2 thinking - System 1 thinking is a near-instantaneous process; it happens automatically, intuitively, and with little effort. It’s driven by instinct and our experiences. System 2 thinking is slower and requires more effort. It is conscious and logical. Daniel Kahneman suggests that 95% of our behaviors are guided by System 1. By understanding how these two systems work, we will gain better insights into understanding the factors that drive those seemingly “mindless” behaviors.
Heuristics and Biases in Judgment and decision making - Heuristics are mental shortcuts that can facilitate problem-solving and probability judgments. These strategies are generalizations, or rules-of-thumb, reduce cognitive load, and can be effective for making immediate judgments.
Design of behavioural change solutions - Students, based on theories covered by this course, design and carry out a service-learning project to help members in their community (College/ family) to change their behaviours so as to promote well-being in the community.
